snippet: The top official in the county that encompasses Chicago said Wednesday that she would drop plans for a nickel-per-bullet tax but would continue support for a $25 tax on firearms.
abstract: Toni Preckwinkle, board president of Cook County, Ill, which encompasses Chicago, says that she will drop plans for a nickel-per-bullet tax but will continue support for $25 tax on firearms; claims that proposed ordinance was more about addressing violence than raising money for the county, which faces a shortfall of $260 million.
lead_paragraph: The top official in the county that encompasses Chicago said Wednesday that she would drop plans for a nickel-per-bullet tax but would continue support for a $25 tax on firearms.

headline.main: Illinois: County’s Plan to Tax Bullets Is Rescinded
headline.print_headline: Illinois: County’s Plan To Tax Bullets Is Rescinded
